Richard M. Young to Abraham Lincoln, 7 May 18491 (Strictly Confidential) As the time is fast approaching, when it is thought some one may be selected as my successor; and as I feel much concern for the welfare of those

who will be left behind me, in this office, with whom I have been in daily intercourse^now,^for upwards of two years, I have thought it would not be amiss to address you a line

at the present juncture, so that you may per adventure (asJudge Scateswould say) by timely interference, prevent, what other wise may happen— that is the appointment of some one who would not be acceptable– You^know^what I said to MrEwingin regard to the successorship— and why not lay modesty aside and strike for yourself–

From what I can learn MrB. ofC.— contrary to what he said to me when you was here, and after having lost the Solicitorship

of the Treasury, is now playing a strong game for theLand Office— some think he will succeed— now cant you prevent, by urging the claims of oneA. Lincoln— who I am sure, would be more acceptable here than anyWhiginIllinois? What say you– Whatever you do, it will be well for it to be done quickly—<Page 2>and I am very sure that you can succeed better with this man Lincoln, than any person

else–

footnotes.text: 1Richard M. Young wrote this letter and postscript and signed the letter.

2Justin H. Butterfield,James L. D. Morrison, andCyrus Edwardswere vying to succeed Young as  commissioner of the U.S. General Land Office.  Abraham
                  Lincoln would  eventually become a candidate for the job, but he did not receive the
                  appointment, the job going to  Butterfield instead. See theGeneral Land Office Affair.
